anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1192 and 1193 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the order

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from order dated January 13, 1969 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in P.A. No. 6 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated January 13, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court, at Chandigarh, in P.A. No. 6 of 1969. Sen and G. D. Gupta, for the appellant.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GROVER, J. These two appeals by certificate from a judgment of the Allahabad High Court must succeed on the short ground that the provisions

facts.text: Two appeals by certificate from judgment of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by certificate from a judgment of the Allahabad High Court must succeed on the short ground that the provisions of s. 4 1  of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, were

facts.text: In C.A. 1192/67, notification under s.4 issued on October 15, 1960 for acquisition of land in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In C.A. 1192/67 a numberification was issued under s. 4 of the Act on October 15, 1960 for acquisition of the land in dispute. Under s. 17  4  of the Act the provisions of s. 5A were dispensed with.

facts.text: Under s.17(4) of the Act, provisions of s.5A dispensed with.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 17  4  of the Act the provisions of s. 5A were dispensed with. On October 28, 1960 the numberification under s. 6 was issued. The appellant was directed to be present before the Collector

facts.text: Notification under s.6 issued on October 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On October 28, 1960 the numberification under s. 6 was issued. The appellant was directed to be present before the Collector in pursuance of a numberice under s. 9 on December 4, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant directed to be present before Collector under s.9 on December 4, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was directed to be present before the Collector in pursuance of a numberice under s. 9 on December 4, 1960. On December 5, 1960 the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the acqui- sition proceedings.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art.226 challenging acquisition proceedings on December 5, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1960 the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the acqui- sition proceedings. The petition, was dismissed by a single judge of the High Court whose judgment was affirmed in Special Appeal by the Division Bench.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by single judge of High Court, judgment affirmed by Division Bench in Special Appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, was dismissed by a single judge of the High Court whose judgment was affirmed in Special Appeal by the Division Bench. Section 4 1  of the Act is in the following terms Whenever it appears to the appropriate Government that land in any locality is needed or is likely to be, needed for any public purpose,

facts.text: Collector did not cause public notice of substance of s.4 notification at convenient places in locality.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Collector did number cause public numberice of the substance of the numberification to be given at companyvenient places in the locality where the land sought to be acquired was situated. In other words there was numbercompliance whatsoever with the second part of sub-s.   1   of s. 4.

facts.text: It is common ground that there was no compliance with second part of s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: In other words there was numbercompliance whatsoever with the second part of sub-s.   1   of s. 4. The law as settled by this Court is that. such a numberice under second part of s. 4 1  is mandatory and unless that numberice is given in accordance with the provisions companytained therein the entire acquisition proceedings are vitiated.

facts.text: Two appeals involve the same point.

anchor.surface_text: In the above view of the matter the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are companysequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals and quashes acquisition proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In the above view of the matter the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are companysequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 requiring public notice of the substance of the notification are mandatory even when provisions of Section 5A are dispensed with under Section 17(4)?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State has, however, contended that according to these decisions it is only when the persons interested can file objections under s. 5-A that the, public notice of the substance of the notification under s. 4 1 by the Collector would be necessary whereas in the present case the, applicability

issues.text: Whether non-compliance with the public notice requirement under the second part of Section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 vitiates the entire acquisition proceedings?

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the Collector did number cause public numberice of the substance of the numberification to be given at companyvenient places in the said locality It is companymon ground that the Collector did number cause public numberice of the substance of the numberification to be given at companyvenient places in the locality where the land sought to be acquired was situated. In other words there was numbercompliance whatsoever with the second part of sub-s.   1   of s. 4. The law as settled by this Court is that. such a numberice under second part of s. 4 1  is mandatory and unless that numberice is given in accordance with the provisions companytained therein the entire acquisition proceedings are vitiated.

arguments.claim: Public notice of the substance of the notification under s.4(1) by the Collector is necessary only when persons interested can file objections under s.5A, but unnecessary when s.5A is dispensed with under s.17(4) as parties are not entitled to file objections

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State has, however, contended that according to these decisions it is only when the persons interested can file objections under s. 5-A that the, public notice of the substance of the notification under s. 4 1 by the Collector would be necessary whereas in the present case the, applicability

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gazette that the land is likely to be needed for any public purpose and the Collector has to cause numberice to be given of the substance of such numb

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions of s.4(1) cannot be held to be mandatory in one situation and directory in another; no distinction contemplated between cases where s.17(4) direction made or not

arguments.claim: Notice under second part of s.4(1) is mandatory and non-compliance vitiates the entire acquisition proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In other words there was no compliance whatsoever with the second part of sub-s.   1   of s. 4. The law as settled by this Court is that. such a notice under second part of s. 4 1  is mandatory and unless that notice is given in accordance with the provisions contained therein the entire acquisition proceedings are vitiated.

arguments.claim: Object of notice under s.4(1) is to give intimation to landowner of intention to enter land under s.4(2); non-compliance makes entry unlawful

anchor.surface_text: We may refer in this connection to Khub Chand Others v. The State of Rajasthan, Ors.  1 . In that case this Court pointed out that the object is to give intimation to a person whose land is sought to be acquired of the intention of the officer to enter the land.

arguments.claim: Both publication in Gazette and local publicity by Collector required for valid s.4 notification; purpose includes enabling objections under s.5A which confers valuable right

anchor.surface_text: In State of Mysore v. Abdul Razak Sahib 2  no notices as required by s. 4 1 of the Act were published in the locality till after the lapse of about 10 weeks. ... The purpose behind such a notice was that interested persons should know that the land is being acquired so. as to prefer any objections under s. 5-A which confers a valuable right.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) provisions cannot be mandatory in some cases and directory in others; no distinction based on s.17(4) dispensation of s.5A

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept such a contention. In our judgment the provisions of s. 4 1  cannot be held to be mandatory in one situation and directory in another. Section 4 1  does not contemplate any distinction between those proceedings in which in exercise of the power under s. 17  4

arguments.claim: s.4(1) requires simultaneously publication in Gazette and public notice by Collector at convenient places; integrated provision with two mandatory conditions

anchor.surface_text: It lays down in unequivocal and clear terms that both things have to be simultaneously done under s. 4 1 , i.e., a notification has to be published in the official gazette that the land is likely to be needed for any public purpose and the Collector has to cause notice to be given of the substance of such notification at convenient places in the locality in which the land is situated.

arguments.claim: Scheme of s.4 is that sub-s.(2) powers exercisable only after compliance with sub-s.(1); s.17(4) does not alter this

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 4 is that after the steps contemplated under sub-s.  1  have been taken the officer authorized by the Government can do the various acts set out in sub-s.  2 .

arguments.claim: Direction under s.17(4) dispensing s.5A can be made simultaneously with or after s.4(1) notification; does not depend construction of s.4(1) on it

anchor.surface_text: It is not required under s. 17 4  of the principal Act that when a notification under s. 4 1  is issued the direction should be made simultaneously if the State Government so desires. Such an order or direction can be made even at a later stage. ... Thus the construction of s. 4 1  cannot be made to depend upon any action or direction which the State Government may choose to make under s. 17  4  of the principal Act.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) is an integrated provision containing two conditions both must be satisfied for compliance

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion s. 4  1  has to be read as an integrated provision which contains two conditions the first is that the notification in the official gazette must be published and the second is that the Collector has to cause public notice of the substance of such notification to be given.

arguments.claim: Non-compliance with s.4(1) shown by common ground; appeals succeed and proceedings quashed

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the Collector did no cause public notice of the substance of the notification to be given at convenient places in the locality where the land sought to be acquired was situated. ... In the above view of the matter the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are consequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed.

holdings.text: such a notice under second part of s. 4 1  is mandatory and unless that notice is given in accordance with the provisions contained therein the entire acquisition proceedings are vitiated

anchor.surface_text: The law as settled by this Court is that. such a numberice under second part of s. 4 1  is mandatory and unless that numberice is given in accordance with the provisions companytained therein the entire acquisition proceedings are vitiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on settled Supreme Court precedents holding the public notice requirement mandatory with vitiating effect on non-compliance

holdings.text: the provisions of s. 4 1  cannot be held to be mandatory in one situation and directory in another

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept such a contention. In our judgment the provisions of s. 4 1  cannot be held to be mandatory in one situation and directory in another. Section 4 1  does not contemplate any distinction between those proceedings in which in exercise of the power under s. 17  4

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.4(1) contemplates no distinction based on whether s.17(4) dispenses with s.5A; provisions uniformly mandatory

holdings.text: both things have to be simultaneously done under s. 4 1 , i.e., a notification has to be published in the official gazette [...] and the Collector has to cause notice to be given of the substance of such notification at convenient places in the locality

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 1  does not contemplate any distinction between those proceedings in which in exercise of the power under s. 17  4  the appropriate government directs that the provisions of s. 5-A shall not apply and where such a direction has not been made dispensing with the applicability of S. 5A. It lays down in unequivocal and clear terms that both things have to be simultaneously done under s. 4 1 , i.e., a notification has to be published in the official gazette that the land is likely to be needed for any public purpose and the Collector has to cause notice to be given of the substance of such notification at convenient places in the locality in which the land is situated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear and unequivocal statutory language requires simultaneous gazette publication and local public notice as integrated steps

holdings.text: s. 4  1  has to be read as an integrated provision which contains two conditions the first is that the notification in the official gazette must be published and the second is that the Collector has to cause public notice of the substance of such notification to be given

anchor.surface_text: Thus the construction of s. 4 1  cannot be made to depend upon any action or direction which the State Government may choose to make under s. 17  4  of the principal Act. In our opinion s. 4  1  has to be read as an integrated provision which contains two conditions the first is that the notification in the official gazette must be published and the second is that the Collector has to cause public notice of the substance of such notification to be given. These two conditions must be satisfied for the purpose of compliance with the provisions of s. 4 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) structured as single provision with two interdependent mandatory conditions for validity

holdings.text: the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are consequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed

anchor.surface_text: In the above view of the matter the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are consequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed.

It lays down in unequivocal and clear terms that both things have to be simultaneously done under s. 4 1 , i.e., a notification has to be published in the official gazette that the land is likely to be needed for any public purpose and the Collector has to cause notice to be given of the substance of such notification at convenient places in the locality in which the land is situated.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the construction of s. 4 1  cannot be made to depend upon any action or direction which the State Government may choose to make under s. 17  4  of the principal Act. In our opinion s. 4  1  has to be read as an integrated provision which contains two conditions the first is that the notification in the official gazette must be published and the second is that the Collector has to cause public notice of the substance of such notification to be given. These two conditions must be satisfied for the purpose of compliance with the provisions of s. 4 1 .

In the above view of the matter the appeals which involve the same point must succeed. They are consequently allowed and the acquisition proceedings in question in both the appeals shall stand quashed.
